Catalytic Induced Thermal Conversion of Amorphous Carbon into Single
Walled Carbon Nanotubes
Ravi Joshi a,b , Roland Schierholz c , Jörg J. Schneider* ,a , and Prathap Haridoss c
Darmstadt, Technische Universität Darmstadt, a Eduard-Zintl-Institut für Anorganische und Physikalische Chemie b Fachbereich Chemie
c Madras, Chennai/India, Indian Institute of Technology, Department of Metallurgy and Materials Engineering
Received October 31 st , 2007.
Dedicated to ProfessorKlaus Hafner on the Occasion of his 80 th Birthday
Abstract. Single walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs) have caught
extensive attention in the field of material science and electronics.
Their formation typically uses plasma arc or CVD techniques
[1Ϫ3]. So far, formation of SWCNTs just by thermal conversion
of amorphous, non graphitic carbon which is a nearly ubiquitous
carbon source is challenging but has not been reported so far. We
herein demonstrate the catalytic growth of SWNTs from an
text.body:
Introduction
It is well known that amorphous carbon, upon heat treat-
ment (2500°Ϫ3500°C), undergoes crystallization forming
graphite [4]. Addition of alkaline or alkaline earth metals
catalyze this process, resulting into faster graphitization at
lower temperature.
The role of metallic nickel in graphitizing thin films of
amorphous carbon at 1000°C has also been reported [5].
Along the same route, the metal combination nickel/yttrium
plays a crucial role in the catalyzed growth of SWNTs and
its influence has been studied experimentally and theoreti-
cally [6Ϫ8]. It has been speculated that the degree of carbon
solubility in the catalyst is a major criterion for a metal to
catalyze growth of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [7, 8]. If this
criterion is satisfied experimentally, amorphous carbon
(charcoal) could be used as a convenient carbon source to
grow SWCNTs. So far, to the best of our knowledge this
hypothesis has not been proven experimentally and the di-
rect catalytically driven conversion of amorphous carbon
over metals into SWCNTs is not known.
Results and Discussion

Yttrium oxide and either metallic nickel or bis(η 5 -cyclopen-

1800°C each. Under these conditions carbon will reduce
yttrium oxide to yttrium metal. Bis(η 5 -cyclopentadienyl)-
nickel serves as an alternative source for metallic nickel
which is generated therefrom via thermal decomposition
[9]. Work reported herein is based on the phenomenon of
absorption and dissolution of amorphous carbon by metal
particles at high temperature followed by expulsion of gra-
phitic carboneous species therefrom when the saturation
limit of carbon in the catalyst particle is reached.
In a controlexperiment, plain activated charcoal powder,
without addition of any catalyst material, was heated to
1500°C. This leads to formation of disordered graphitic
structures. No formation of CNTs was observed under
these reaction conditions. Though graphitization had oc-
curred to a certain extent under these conditions, almost
the entire sample has been converted into glassy carbon
which is identified by a high intensity defect band in its
Raman spectrum (Fig 1a). The same morphology and ex-
tent of graphitization was found when the sample was
heated higher, up to 1800°C.
When amorphous carbon is heated with a mixture of
bis(η 5 -cyclopentadienyl)nickel and yttrium oxide as catalyst
up to 1500°C, a conversion of the carbon source into still
disordered graphitic material was observed as it was found
in the uncatalyzed reaction sample (Fig 2a). However,
when increasing the temperature further to 1800°C,
growth of bundles of SWCNTs was indeed observed
(Fig. 1b, Fig 2b). The inter layer spacing of the SWCNT
structures is more than the typical graphitic 0.34 nm spac-
ing, and is close to 1 nm while their length range in the
order of several nanometers. In spite of the CNT structures

Metallic nickel proved to be the most effective catalyst for
the formation of CNTs via thermal conversion of charcoal
powder. Bundles of SWCNTs were formed when heating
charcoal samples with metallic nickel and yttrium oxide up
text.note: Conversion of Amorphous Carbon into Single Walled Carbon Nanotubes
text.body:
to 1800°C. Bundles as small as two tubes and as large as
containing few tens of tubes have been observed (Fig.3b,
3c). The SAED pattern shows distinguished (002) spots and
a double hexagonal structure generated by electron diffrac-
tion from (hk0) plane. The smallest single walled nanotube
that has been observed in the present work has a diameter
of 0.57 nm, while the widest tube diameter observed was
1.3 nm. Interestingly catalyst particles formed at 1800°C
either from nickel metal/yttrium oxide or nickelocene/
yttrium oxide, were often covered with a layer of graphite
(fig 3a and 3c). While synthesis temperatures of 1800°C
produced mainly SWCNTs, synthesis temperatures limited
up to 1500°C revealed the formation of mainly MWCNTs
(TEM analysis, no figure shown).
In a second control experiment we have treated a sample
of a purified carbon soot material which we have obtained
from a plasma arc discharge experiment under the same
catalytic conditions (catalyst system: metallic nickel, yttrium
oxide) [10]. Such a purified carbon soot contains mainly
multi walled CNTs. The control experiment showed no for-
mation of SWCNTs directly from the soot containing
MWCNTs.

The degree of graphitization of SWCNTs formed, was
evaluated by determining the ratio of the defect band (I D )
to the graphitic band (I G ) [11]. The (I D /I G ) ratio is found to
be a maximum for a sample containing no catalyst (Fig.1a).
When the catalyst system metallic nickel/yttrium oxide was
used the (I D /I G ) ratio decreased drastically indicating good
graphitization of the CNTs. The degree of graphitization
was in the same range when nickelocene instead of metallic
nickel was used as Ni source in the catalyst system.
We observed different types of complex metallic in-
terphases formed from the catalyst precursor mixtures
Ni particles /yttrium oxide during CNT formation and charac-
terized them of situ via X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Fig.4).
Intermetallics of nickel and yttrium (Ni 2 Y 3 , Y 2 Ni 7 ) [12] as
well as nickel nitride Ni 3 N [13] and boron oxide (B 13 O 2 ϭ
B 12 (OBO) [13] could be identified. In addition to the gra-
phitic (002) peak of the CNTs a characteristic peak for the
formation of carbolite, a carbon allotrope composed of
macromolecular polyene chains [-CϵCϵC-] or cumulene
[-CϭCϭCϭC-] fragments, could be identified [15]. This
peak confirms the graphitization of amorphous carbon. No
further signals corresponding to yttrium oxide where found.

As expected no signals corresponding to graphitic struc-
tures were found in the catalyst free only heat treated char-
coal samples.
Thermogravimetric studies of carboneous material ob-
tained from thermal treatment of charcoal samples at
1800°C without any catalyst in air confirm oxidation of
the formed graphitic material starting at already 400°C, the
weight loss contains until 700°C at which only a negligible
total residue of material is left, indicating that no CNTs
have been formed under these conditions (< 1 %, Fig. 5a).
In contrast, heating product samples obtained from a reac-
tion of charcoal with the catalyst system Ni metal /Y 2 O 3 at
1800°C in air start oxidizing from 600°C upwards. Oxidat-
ive decomposition proceeds up to 900°C, but no further
weight loss was observed when keeping that temperature or
increasing it further up to 1000°C [17]. The amount of
residual material left at that temperature, composed of
CNTs is about 30 % (Fig.5b).

In our reactions the rate of carbon absorption into the cata-
lyst particles was high, compared to the segregation rate
and was governed by an uniform cooling rate approaching
nearly isothermal conditions. This might lead to nucleation
of SWCNT embryos at numerous locations on the surface
of the catalyst particles. Three mechanistic scenarios have
been postulated for carbon segregation on a (111) metallic
nickel surface explaining graphitization at high tempera-
tures [18]. In the first scenario (i) a solid solution of catalyst
particle and carbon forms, in the second (ii) a graphitic
monolayer grown over the solid solution formed during
cooling of the complete reaction system. From this graphitic
monolayer an epitaxial onion like graphitic precipitate can
form in latter stages on the surface of the encapsulated catalyst
particles (iii). This may then preclude CNT growth.
We observed formation of numerous bundles of SWNTs in
our thermal synthesis process onto individual catalyst par-
ticles at 1800°C. Catalytic formation of SWNTs has indeed
be found to start at about 1227°C [19], which is 573°C
lower than our thermally activitated catalytic conversion
process of amorphous carbon. If nucleation of SWNT em-
bryos were formed before the reaction system reaches stage
(i), then an uniform growth of bundles of SWCNTs in dif-
ferent directions originating from the catalyst surface (so
text.note: Conversion of Amorphous Carbon into Single Walled Carbon Nanotubes
text.body:
called sea urchin structure [8, 19]) will be formed. However,
no such structure could be detected in our samples by
TEM studies.
Our thermal reaction conditions employed obviously favor
the formation of stages (ii) and (iii), where catalyst particles
are completely surrounded by a thick graphitic layer (see
Fig. 3a). This dense, closed carbon graphene layer can pre-
clude formation of CNTs on the intermetallic catalyst par-
ticles [8, 20]. Even when only a mono-or multilayer of
graphite is formed over the catalyst particles, it precludes
CNT embryo formation from which typically any CNT
growth proceeds. In such a scenario CNT growth is then
only possible under two circumstances. First, either a sur-
factant, e.g. a rare earth metal Ϫ as it is present in our
process Ϫ alloys with the catalyst surface and avoids its
complete wetting by carbon. This could allow for CNT
growth in such non wetted areas were the catalyst particle's
surface is still accessible. In the case if no such surfactant
is available, further CNT growth is only possible if the
graphite monolayer is not completely closed at a constant
rate. This may be caused by a relative motion of catalyst
particle and monolayer carbon shell [20].
Conclusion
To conclude, we have shown that SWCNT formation is pos-
sible via a thermal, catalytically induced process starting
from amorphous charcoal powder (Aktivkohle). The active
catalyst particles are intermetallic phases of defined Ni x /Y y
composition. Since amorphous charcoal is an ubiquitous
carbon source our process provides an unique way for ob-
taining SWCNTs from this cheap and convenient source.
The studies show that under similar conditions no forma-
tion of SWCNTs from graphitic material e.g. MWCNTs
seems possible. Thus the carbon source obviously has to be
non graphitic to allow for efficient reactivity and dissol-
ution of carbon in the catalytic intermetallic particles. Our
active catalyst system contains a surfactant metal (Y) which
may preclude the complete surface wetting and thus the
deactivation of the catalyst particles by hindering the for-
mation of a completely closed carbon shell on the particles.
This assures that the growth process on the surface of the
catalyst particles is not arrested and leads to SWCNT for-
mation.
Experimental Section
Experiments were carried out in two individual sets, each at tem-
peratures of 1500°and 1800°C of four different samples (pellets
1Ϫ4) listed below. Metallic nickel (powder, 200 mesh, Merck) or
bis(η 5 -cyclopentadienyl)nickel and yttrium oxide (Aldrich) were
used as catalyst precursors. Crushed activated charcoal powder
('Aktivkohle') was used as amorphous carbon source. Cellulose was
used as pellet binder. The element ratio of nickel to yttrium was
4:1 in our experiments as well as in the arc discharge method em-

fied arc discharge soot containing MWNTs.
